choices.text: Forced expiratory volume in 1 second/forced vital capacity (FEV1/FVC) ratio

questions.text: Which pulmonary function test may be altered to a similar degree in both restrictive lung disease and obstructive lung disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tidal volume is usually preserved or altered to a similar mild degree in both obstructive and restrictive lung diseases because it reflects normal quiet breathing.

  • Pulmonary function tests measure different aspects of lung volumes and airflow.
  • Obstructive lung disease (e.g., COPD, asthma) is characterized by airflow limitation. Key PFT changes include increased residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC) due to air trapping, while tidal volume (VT) often remains relatively normal. FEV1 is markedly reduced, and FEV1/FVC ratio is decreased.
  • Restrictive lung disease (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis, interstitial lung disease) is characterized by decreased lung compliance and reduced lung volumes. TLC, vital capacity (VC), and residual volume are reduced. VT may remain near normal as patients adapt by increasing breathing frequency rather than depth. FEV1 and FVC are reduced proportionally, so FEV1/FVC ratio is normal or slightly increased.
  • Key point: Tidal volume, which represents the volume of air exchanged during quiet breathing, is usually preserved in both conditions, unlike residual volume, total lung capacity, or FEV1/FVC ratio, which show disease-specific changes.

Explanation of incorrect options

Residual volume (Option A): Increased in obstructive disease due to air trapping, decreased or normal in restrictive disease.

Total lung capacity (Option C): Increased in obstructive disease (hyperinflation) and decreased in restrictive disease.

FEV1/FVC ratio (Option D): Decreased in obstructive disease, normal or increased in restrictive disease; changes are not similar between the two.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has been a smoker of 20 a day for 30 years. He had a cough and difficulty in breathing for 3 days, which worsened, and he presented to the hospital. He has home nebulisers but not home oxygen. On examination, his oxygen saturation is 95%, blood pressure 110 / 60 mmHg and respiratory rate 32. He has diffuse wheezing and is using his respiratory muscles. Arterial blood gases done on 6 litres of oxygen show: pH 7.25, pO2 120 mmHg, pCO2 61.5 mmHg. What should be the next management step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has acute-on-chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure due to COPD; high oxygen can worsen CO2 retention, so oxygen should be carefully titrated.

  • The patient is a chronic smoker with probable COPD, presenting with an acute exacerbation.
  • Clinical features: tachypnea, accessory muscle use, diffuse wheeze.
  • ABG analysis on high-flow oxygen shows:
    • pH 7.25 → acidotic
    • pCO2 61.5 mmHg → hypercapnia
    • pO2 120 mmHg → hyperoxemia (likely due to high-flow oxygen)
  • Key concept:
    • Patients with chronic hypercapnia may rely on hypoxic drive for respiration.
    • High inspired oxygen can reduce respiratory drive, worsen V/Q mismatch, and cause CO2 retention, leading to worsening acidosis (type II respiratory failure).
    • Management:
      • Titrate oxygen to target SpO2 88-92% rather than giving high-flow oxygen.
      • Only escalate to non-invasive ventilation (NIV) if hypercapnia worsens or the patient shows signs of exhaustion, severe acidosis (pH <7.25), or altered consciousness.
      • Intubation is reserved for NIV failure.

Explanation of incorrect options

Non-invasive ventilation (Option A): Not immediately indicated because the patient's pH is 7.25, and he is currently maintaining oxygenation; the priority is correcting oxygen therapy first.

Intubation and ventilation (Option B): Not indicated yet; invasive ventilation is for patients with NIV failure or impending respiratory arrest.

Increase oxygen concentration (Option D): Dangerous in COPD exacerbation with hypercapnia; can worsen CO2 retention and acidosis.

choices.text: Refer to a respiratory outpatient clinic

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with emphysema presented with increasing dyspnoea and left-sided pleuritic chest pain. A chest radiograph reveals a left-sided pneumothorax with a lung edge measured 5 cm away from the chest wall. The most appropriate management of his condition is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A large pneumothorax (>2-3 cm) or symptomatic pneumothorax requires immediate intercostal tube drainage to re-expand the lung and prevent complications.

  • Pneumothorax is classified by size:
    • Small: <2-3 cm from lung margin to chest wall
    • Large: >2-3 cm
  • Symptoms and risk factors: Dyspnea, pleuritic pain, underlying lung disease (emphysema) increase the risk of deterioration.
  • Management:
    • Small, asymptomatic primary pneumothorax → can be observed with supplemental oxygen and serial X-rays.
    • Large (>2-3 cm) or symptomatic pneumothorax, or secondary pneumothorax in patients with underlying lung disease (like emphysema) → intercostal tube drainage is indicated.
  • In this patient, the lung edge is 5 cm → large pneumothorax. Underlying emphysema classifies it as secondary pneumothorax, so observation alone is unsafe.

Explanation of incorrect options

Review with daily chest radiographs (Option A): Unsafe for large or symptomatic secondary pneumothorax; can lead to respiratory compromise.

Refer to a respiratory outpatient clinic (Option C): Delays urgent treatment; not appropriate in acute, symptomatic large pneumothorax.

CT chest (Option D): Not required acutely for diagnosis; chest X-ray is sufficient for initial management. CT is reserved for recurrent, atypical, or complicated cases.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man attends the hospital with a history of proximal muscle weakness. He also gives a history of a cough of 12 weeks duration and complains of pain in the small joints of the hands. He has small haemorrhages in the nail folds, but is not clubbed. On examination of the chest, he has bibasal crackles, and a chest radiograph reveals diffuse reticular infiltrates. Lung function tests confirm a restrictive pattern. What is the likely cause of his interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermatomyositis is associated with proximal muscle weakness, characteristic skin findings, and can cause a restrictive interstitial lung disease with reticular infiltrates.

  • Dermatomyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy presenting with:
    • Proximal muscle weakness (shoulder and hip girdle)
    • Skin manifestations: Gottron's papules over joints, nailfold haemorrhages, heliotrope rash
    • Systemic features: Arthralgia, ILD, and rarely cardiac involvement
  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD) in dermatomyositis:
    • Presents with dry cough, exertional dyspnea, bibasal crackles
    • Radiology: Diffuse reticular or ground-glass infiltrates
    • Pulmonary function: restrictive pattern (↓FVC, ↓TLC)
  • In this patient:
    • Proximal weakness + nailfold haemorrhages → dermatomyositis
    • Chronic cough + bibasal crackles + restrictive PFT → ILD secondary to dermatomyositis
  • Other clues: Small joint pain may reflect associated inflammatory arthritis; absence of clubbing does not rule out ILD.

Explanation of incorrect options

SLE (Option A): Can cause ILD, but muscle weakness is usually not a prominent feature; skin findings are different (malar rash, photosensitivity).

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option C): Can cause upper-lobe fibrosis but usually presents with chronic back pain, spinal stiffness, and HLA-B27 positivity; distal small joint involvement is uncommon.

Cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis (Option D): Also known as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis; presents as restrictive ILD with basal reticular infiltrates, but muscle weakness and nailfold changes are absent, helping differentiate from connective tissue disease-associated ILD.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is referred for investigation of the cause of chronic cough. He describes long-standing sputum production, which is streaked with blood. There is no fever or night sweats, and he does not smoke. However, there is a family history of such symptoms. Chest X-ray shows mild bilateral lower zone shadowing. Which is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High-resolution CT (HRCT) is the most sensitive modality for evaluating structural lung abnormalities in patients with chronic productive cough, especially when bronchiectasis is suspected.

  • The patient's features suggest bronchiectasis:
    • Chronic productive cough with hemoptysis
    • Bilateral lower zone shadowing on X-ray
    • Positive family history (possible underlying genetic cause like cystic fibrosis or primary ciliary dyskinesia)
  • High-resolution CT (HRCT) is the investigation of choice because:
    • It can detect bronchial dilatation, wall thickening, and mucus plugging, which may not be visible on plain chest X-ray.
    • It helps identify the pattern and extent of disease, which guides management.
  • Other investigations are less appropriate at this stage:

Explanation of incorrect options

Exercise tolerance test (Option B): Cannot visualize structural lung pathology; only measures functional capacity.

Echocardiography (Option C): Unnecessary in absence of cardiac symptoms or signs; does not evaluate bronchial pathology.

Bronchoscopy and biopsy (Option D): Invasive; indicated only for localized lesions, unexplained hemoptysis, or suspected malignancy; not required for diffuse bronchiectasis diagnosis.

CT findings of bronchiectasis:

  • Tram track appearance (tubular bronchiectasis)
  • Grape bunch appearance (cystic bronchiectasis)
  • Signet ringsign (a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 5 times that of the adjacent vessel)
  • Lack of peripheral tapering of bronchi (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cmfrom the pleural surface)
  • Finger in glove appearance
  • Tree in budappearance: due to inspissated secretions

choices.text: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a history of worsening breathlessness and cough. His arterial blood gases show the following recordings when taken at room air: pH 7.25, pO2 48 mmHg, pCO2 66.75 mmHg, bicarbonate 31mmol/L What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ABG shows type II respiratory failure (hypoxemia with hypercapnia and acidosis) typical of an acute exacerbation of COPD.

  • ABG analysis:
    • pH 7.25 → acidotic
    • pCO2 66.75 mmHg → hypercapnia
    • pO2 48 mmHg → hypoxemia
    • Bicarbonate 31 mmol/L → metabolic compensation (chronic CO2 retention)
  • This pattern is acute-on-chronic respiratory failure seen in acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD):
    • Chronic COPD patients retain CO2, leading to partially compensated metabolic alkalosis.
    • Exacerbations (usually triggered by infection or irritants) can cause worsening hypoxia, hypercapnia, and acidemia.
  • Clinical features: Worsening dyspnea, cough, and history of chronic lung disease.

Explanation of incorrect options

Obstructive sleep apnoea (Option B): Causes intermittent nocturnal hypoxemia and hypercapnia, not persistent daytime type II respiratory failure.

Pulmonary oedema (Option C): Usually causes hypoxemia without significant hypercapnia initially; ABG typically shows type I respiratory failure (low pO2, normal/low pCO2).

Pulmonary embolus (Option D): Typically causes sudden hypoxemia with respiratory alkalosis (low pCO2) due to hyperventilation, not hypercapnia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old gentleman has Pickwickian syndrome. He has poor exercise tolerance of 50 yards and often feels lethargic at work. Which of the following is the best investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pickwickian syndrome (obesity hypoventilation syndrome) is primarily diagnosed and evaluated using a sleep study (polysomnography) to detect nocturnal hypoventilation and sleep-disordered breathing.

  • Pickwickian syndrome (obesity hypoventilation syndrome, OHS):
    • Characterized by obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), chronic daytime hypercapnia, and sleep-disordered breathing, usually obstructive sleep apnoea.
    • Symptoms: excessive daytime sleepiness, lethargy, morning headaches, poor exercise tolerance.
  • Investigation of choice:
    • Polysomnography (sleep study) confirms sleep apnoea and nocturnal hypoventilation, guiding management with CPAP or BiPAP therapy.

Explanation of incorrect options

Echocardiography to assess cor pulmonale (Option A): Useful to assess right heart strain from chronic hypoxia but does not diagnose OHS.

CT scan of the chest (Option B): Not required unless other lung pathology is suspected; does not evaluate sleep apnoea.

Blood gas (Option C): Can show daytime hypercapnia and hypoxemia, but cannot detect nocturnal hypoventilation or apnoea episodes, which define the syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man smoker of 35 pack years, presents with a 6-month history of shortness of breath. His past medical history includes diabetes and cervical spondylosis. Spirometry shows FEV1 of 1 litre - 65% predicted, 1.03 litres - 57% predicted, FEV1/FVC ratio of 95. How would you interpret the spirometry results?
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

A high or normal FEV1/FVC ratio with proportionally reduced FEV1 and FVC indicates a restrictive ventilatory defect.

  • Spirometry patterns:
    • Obstructive defect: FEV1 ↓, FVC normal or slightly ↓, FEV1/FVC ↓ (<70%)
    • Restrictive defect: FEV1 ↓, FVC ↓ proportionally, FEV1/FVC normal or ↑
    • Mixed defect: Features of both obstruction and restriction (FEV1 ↓, FVC ↓, FEV1/FVC ↓)
  • In this patient:
    • FEV1 and FVC are both reduced (FEV1 65%, FVC 57%)
    • FEV1/FVC ratio is 95% (elevated) → obstruction is unlikely
    • Pattern is consistent with restrictive lung disease, possibly due to interstitial lung disease, obesity, or musculoskeletal limitation from cervical spondylosis.

Explanation of incorrect options

Normal (Option A): FEV1 and FVC are below predicted values; not normal.

Mixed defect (Option B): FEV1/FVC ratio would be reduced if obstruction coexists, which it is not.

Obstructive defect (Option C): FEV1/FVC ratio would be decreased (<70%), which is not the case.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has worsening breathlessness. He has a past medical history of arthritis and palpitations. On admission, his oxygen saturation was 90% on air. ABGs show pO2 67 mmhg. pCO2 26 mmHg, pH 7.36. His chest X-ray shows patchy shadowing in both lung peripheries. Which one of the following drugs is likely to be responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amiodarone can cause drug-induced interstitial lung disease, presenting with hypoxemia, restrictive physiology, and bilateral peripheral infiltrates.

  • Clinical clues:
    • Worsening breathlessness in an elderly patient on amiodarone for palpitations
    • ABG shows type I respiratory failure (hypoxemia with low pCO2 due to hyperventilation)
    • Chest X-ray: bilateral peripheral patchy infiltrates
  • Amiodarone-induced pulmonary toxicity (AIPT):
    • Occurs in 5-15% of patients on long-term therapy
    • Can manifest as interstitial pneumonitis, organizing pneumonia, or ARDS
    • Risk factors: older age, higher cumulative dose, pre-existing lung disease
  • Other drugs:
    • Codeine, tramadol → opioid respiratory depression; typically cause hypercapnia, not hypoxemia with low pCO2 (Options A,B ruled out)
    • Simvastatin → rare pulmonary toxicity, usually not with this radiographic pattern (Option C ruled out)

Drugs causing pulmonary fibrosis (AB3CTNM2):

  • Amiodarone
  • Bleomycin, Bromocriptine, Busulfan
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • TNF alpha inhibitors
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Methotrexate, Mitomycin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Spirometry confirms severe COPD with a FEV1 of less than 25% predicted. In the last year, he has been admitted to the hospital on 6 occasions with COPD exacerbation. Which one of the following can help reduce hospital admissions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tiotropium, a long-acting anticholinergic bronchodilator, reduces COPD exacerbations and hospital admissions more effectively than other bronchodilators.

  • Severe COPD with frequent exacerbations is a marker of high morbidity and mortality.
  • Tiotropium:
    • Long-acting muscarinic antagonist (LAMA)
    • Reduces airway obstruction and hyperinflation
    • Evidence shows reduction in exacerbation frequency and hospitalizations, especially in severe COPD

Explanation of incorrect options

Montelukast (Option B): Not indicated for COPD; mainly used in asthma and allergic rhinitis.

Oral theophyllines (Option C): Limited efficacy and increased adverse effects; not first-line for preventing hospitalizations.

Salmeterol (Option D): LABA improves symptoms and lung function, but is less effective than tiotropium in reducing severe exacerbations requiring hospitalization.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male has recent onset breathlessness. He has a history of wheezing particularly during the summer when the pollen count is high. Which of these tests would help to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A bronchodilator reversibility test demonstrates reversible airway obstruction, which is diagnostic for asthma.

  • Clinical suspicion: Seasonal wheezing triggered by pollen suggests allergic (extrinsic) asthma.
  • Bronchodilator test:
    • Spirometry is performed to measure FEV1.
    • A ≥12% and ≥200 mL increase in FEV1 after inhaled short-acting bronchodilator confirms reversible airflow obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

Explanation of incorrect options

Trial of inhaled corticosteroids (Option A): Therapeutic approach, not diagnostic.

Serial peak flow measurements (Option C): Useful for monitoring trends, not for initial confirmation.

Lung function tests (Option D): Baseline testing shows obstruction, but diagnosis requires demonstration of reversibility.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with COPD presents with cough and breathlessness, which has worsened over 2 months. On admission, he has the following arterial blood gas results. pH 7.32, pO2 52 mmhg, pCO2 60 mmhg, HCO3 34mmol/l, Base Excess -1. Which one of the following biochemical states fits best?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has hypercapnia with renal compensation, consistent with chronic respiratory acidosis, typically seen in COPD.

  • ABG analysis:
    • pH 7.32 → acidemia (mild)
    • pCO2 60 mmHg → hypercapnia
    • HCO3- 34 mmol/L → elevated, indicating renal compensation
  • Interpretation:
    • Respiratory acidosis: caused by hypoventilation → CO2 retention → ↓pH
    • Chronicity: The presence of elevated bicarbonate indicates renal compensation, suggesting chronic respiratory acidosis rather than acute.
  • Clinical correlation:
    • COPD causes chronic CO2 retention due to airflow obstruction and alveolar hypoventilation.
    • Hypoxemia (pO2 52 mmHg) also points to chronic respiratory disease.

Explanation of incorrect options

Chronic respiratory alkalosis (Option B): Would show low pCO2 and compensatory low HCO3-, not seen here.

Chronic metabolic acidosis (Option C): HCO3- would be low, not elevated.

Chronic metabolic alkalosis (Option D): HCO3- would be high but pCO2 would typically be normal or elevated due to compensation, but the primary disturbance here is hypercapnia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with breathlessness. Her lung function test results show an FEV1 of 1.2 L (65% of predicted), an FVC of 1.4 L (60% of predicted), with an FEV1/FVC ratio of 82%. The total lung capacity (TLC) is 65% of predicted, the transfer factor for carbon monoxide (TLCO) is 57% of predicted, and the transfer coefficient (KCO) is 105% of predicted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A restrictive ventilatory defect with proportional reduction in FEV1 and FVC, preserved FEV1/FVC ratio, reduced TLC, and normal KCO is characteristic of extrapulmonary restriction such as scoliosis.

  • Interpretation of lung function tests:
    • FEV1 and FVC reduced proportionally → restrictive pattern
    • FEV1/FVC normal (82%) → rules out obstructive disease
    • TLC reduced (65%) → confirms restriction
    • TLCO mildly reduced (57%) but KCO normal (105%) → indicates the alveolar-capillary gas transfer per unit lung volume is preserved, suggesting the problem is extrapulmonary, e.g., chest wall or neuromuscular disease
  • Scoliosis:
    • Causes extrinsic restriction due to thoracic cage deformity
    • Gas exchange per alveolar unit remains normal, hence normal KCO

Explanation of incorrect options

COPD (Option A): Obstructive pattern with ↓FEV1/FVC, not seen here.

Bronchiectasis (Option B): Usually obstructive defect with mucus plugging; TLC may be normal or ↑; KCO often normal, but FEV1/FVC is typically ↓.

Cystic fibrosis (Option C): Mixed pattern with obstructive predominance; FEV1/FVC often ↓; KCO often ↓ due to parenchymal involvement.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a six-month history of cough and breathlessness. On examination, he has clubbing, and there are bilateral fine inspiratory crackles at the bases of his lungs. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral basal shadowing in the lung fields. His blood gases reveal hypoxia with a pO2 of 67 mmHg. What is the best investigation to confirm a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

High-resolution CT (HRCT) is the investigation of choice for diagnosing interstitial lung disease, providing detailed information about the pattern, distribution, and extent of lung involvement.

  • Clinical features suggest ILD:
    • Chronic cough and breathlessness
    • Bibasal fine inspiratory crackles
    • Clubbing
    • Bilateral basal shadowing on X-ray
    • Hypoxia (pO2 67 mmHg)
  • Role of investigations:
    • HRCT chest:
      • Detects and characterizes interstitial patterns (reticular, honeycombing, ground-glass)
      • Determines distribution (basal, peripheral, diffuse)
      • Can guide biopsy if required
  • Lung function tests: Show restrictive pattern and reduced TLCO, helpful for assessment but cannot confirm diagnosis (Option A ruled out)
  • Transbronchial biopsy: Invasive; limited yield for ILD diagnosis, mainly reserved for atypical cases or when histology is needed (Option B ruled out)
  • Serum ACE: Useful in sarcoidosis but not diagnostic for general ILD (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 50-year-old asthmatic treated with a high dose of inhaled corticosteroids develops a skin rash. His routine blood tests show mild renal dysfunction and blood eosinophilia. His chest radiograph is normal. Which blood test should be done next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's asthma, eosinophilia, renal involvement, and rash suggest Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis), which is best evaluated with ANCA testing.

  • Clinical clues:
    • Adult-onset asthma with high-dose corticosteroids
    • Blood eosinophilia
    • Renal involvement (mild dysfunction)
    • Skin rash (vasculitic lesions)
    • Normal chest X-ray (early phase possible)
  • Churg-Strauss syndrome / EGPA:
    • Small- to medium-vessel vasculitis associated with p-ANCA (MPO) positivity in many patients
    • Typical features: asthma, eosinophilia, systemic vasculitis affecting skin, kidneys, and peripheral nerves
  • Role of blood tests:
    • ANCA confirms vasculitic activity and supports diagnosis
    • Other tests (IgE, anti-GBM, Aspergillus precipitins) are less specific to this constellation

Explanation of incorrect options

Total IgE (Option A): May be elevated in asthma or atopy but does not explain systemic vasculitis or renal involvement.

Anti-GBM antibody (Option C): Relevant in Goodpasture syndrome (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with pulmonary hemorrhage), not typically associated with asthma or eosinophilia.

Aspergillus fumigatus precipitins (Option D): Useful for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), which can cause asthma and eosinophilia, but renal involvement and skin rash are not features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has a long history of productive cough. He had complained of frequent chest infections. Examination reveals bilateral inspiratory crackles in the bases of the lungs and clubbing of the fingers. Which of the following treatments is likely to reduce the frequency of exacerbations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Postural drainage helps clear retained secretions in bronchiectasis, thereby reducing recurrent infections and exacerbations.

  • Clinical features suggest bronchiectasis:
    • Chronic productive cough with frequent chest infections
    • Bilateral basal crackles
    • Clubbing of fingers
  • Management focus:
    • Prevent recurrent infections and maintain airway clearance
    • Airway clearance techniques (postural drainage, chest physiotherapy, and devices like oscillatory PEP) are cornerstone therapy
  • Other therapies:
    • Prophylactic antibiotics may be used selectively in frequent exacerbators, but airway clearance is more universally recommended (Option A ruled out)
    • Inhaled corticosteroids → limited role unless there is coexisting asthma or eosinophilic inflammation (Option B ruled out)
    • Oral corticosteroids → not recommended for routine bronchiectasis management; used only in exacerbations or underlying inflammatory disease (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady has been complaining of worsening difficulty with breathing over the past year. She has previously been diagnosed with a goitre. On examination, she had marked stridor. Which of the following helps investigate the extent of airway obstruction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A flow-volume loop is the best test to assess the site and severity of fixed or variable airway obstruction, such as extrinsic compression from a goitre.

  • Clinical context:
    • Stridor indicates upper airway obstruction
    • Goitre can cause tracheal compression, which may not be reflected in routine spirometry values alone
  • Flow-volume loop:
    • Provides dynamic assessment of airflow during inspiration and expiration
    • Can distinguish between variable extrathoracic, variable intrathoracic, or fixed upper airway obstruction
    • Helps plan further management, such as surgical intervention
  • Other spirometry measures:
    • FEV1→ reflects overall expiratory flow; reduced in obstruction but does not localize it (Option A ruled out)
    • FVC → measures total air exhaled; less useful in detecting upper airway obstruction (Option B ruled out)
    • Residual volume → assesses trapped air; not helpful for upper airway obstruction (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady has arthritic changes on her hand joints of ulnar deviation and Boutonniere's deformity. She has chronic breathlessness. Which of the following is a likely association?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid arthritis can be associated with interstitial lung disease, leading to pulmonary fibrosis and chronic breathlessness.

  • Clinical clues:
    • Chronic polyarthritis with classic hand deformities → rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
    • Chronic breathlessness in RA raises suspicion for RA-associated interstitial lung disease (RA-ILD)
  • Pulmonary fibrosis in RA:
    • Usually presents as restrictive lung disease with reduced TLC and impaired gas transfer
    • HRCT shows basal and subpleural reticulation, honeycombing, or ground-glass changes
    • Risk factors: long-standing RA, male sex, smoking
  • Other pulmonary conditions:
    • Aspergillosis → usually occurs in immunocompromised or pre-existing cavities; not directly associated with RA (Option A ruled out)
    • Empyema → acute complication; no chronic pattern (Option C ruled out)
    • Lung carcinoma → increased risk in RA patients who smoke, but less directly associated with chronic restrictive lung disease (Option D ruled out)

The pulmonary complications of rheumatoid arthritis are:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis (interstitial lung disease) - UIP pattern (usual interstitial pneumonia)
  • Bronchiolitis obliterans with organising pneumonia
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Interstitial pneumonitis secondary to drugs (eg, Methotrexate)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has significant wheezing and breathlessness. Recordings of peak flows show diurnal variation. He was prescribed salbutamol but continues to have frequent wheezy episodes. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent symptoms despite short-acting β-agonists indicate moderate persistent asthma, which requires inhaled corticosteroids plus a long-acting β-agonist (LABA) like formoterol.

  • Clinical assessment:
    • Frequent symptoms despite short-acting β-agonist → not well-controlled asthma
    • Diurnal variation in peak flow confirms airway hyperresponsiveness
  • Stepwise management (GINA guidelines):
    • Step 1: PRN short-acting β-agonist
    • Step 2: Add low-dose inhaled corticosteroid if symptoms persist
    • Step 3: Moderate persistent asthma → low- or medium-dose ICS + LABA (e.g., formoterol)
  • Rationale for combination therapy:
    • ICS → reduces airway inflammation
    • LABA → improves bronchodilation, prevents nocturnal and exercise-induced symptoms
  • Other options:
    • Leukotriene antagonists → alternative or adjunct; less effective than ICS + LABA in moderate persistent asthma

questions.text: A 70-year-old retired sandblaster has worsening symptoms of cough, wheeze and breathlessness. He has been keeping parrots for 15 years as a hobby. Serum precipitins for M faeni are negative. Chest X-ray showed hyperinflated lungs. His lung function tests show: FEV1 1.8L (predicted 2.6), FVC 3.0L (predicted 3.2), FEV1/FVC 60% Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has airflow obstruction with reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and hyperinflation, consistent with COPD, likely due to occupational exposure and smoking history.

  • Clinical features:
    • Long history of cough, wheeze, breathlessness
    • Hyperinflated lungs on X-ray → characteristic of emphysema
  • Lung function pattern:
    • FEV1 reduced (1.8 L / 69% predicted)
    • FVC near normal → FEV1/FVC 60% → obstructive pattern
    • TLC not provided, but hyperinflation on X-ray supports air trapping

Explanation of incorrect options

Silicosis (Option A): Typically restrictive with upper-lobe nodular opacities; airflow obstruction uncommon early.

Farmer's lung (Option C): Restrictive disease due to hypersensitivity pneumonitis; serum precipitins negative here.

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (Option D): Usually presents in asthma patients with central bronchiectasis and elevated IgE; no such features reported.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man who smokes has progressive breathlessness. He has had a long history of recurrent chest infections. His lung function tests show a FEV1/FVC ratio of 65%, reduced FEV1, FVC and KCO of 45% predicted. He also has an uncle who had a similar presentation. Which is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Early-onset emphysema with family history, particularly in a young smoker with reduced diffusion capacity, is suggestive of alpha-1 antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency.

  • Clinical features:
    • Young age of onset (<40 years)
    • Progressive dyspnea and recurrent chest infections
    • Family history of similar pulmonary disease
  • Pulmonary function:
    • FEV1/FVC <70% → obstructive pattern
    • KCO reduced → impaired gas transfer typical of emphysema
    • FVC reduced due to hyperinflation in emphysema
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:
    • Genetic disorder (autosomal codominant) → deficient A1AT → unchecked neutrophil elastase activity → early panacinar emphysema
    • Often affects lower lobes
    • Exacerbated by smoking

Explanation of incorrect options

Eosinophilic granuloma (Option A): Typically presents with localized lytic lesions, not diffuse early-onset emphysema.

Asthma (Option B): Reversible airflow obstruction; family history and reduced KCO do not match.

Fibrosing alveolitis (Option D): Restrictive pattern (FEV1/FVC >80%), basal fibrosis; KCO may be reduced but pattern differs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman had a CXR showing pulmonary fibrosis. Upon review of her drug history, which of the following drugs might she have been on in the past?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Busulphan is a chemotherapeutic agent known to cause drug-induced pulmonary fibrosis.

  • Drug-induced pulmonary fibrosis:
    • Certain drugs can lead to interstitial lung disease, presenting with progressive dyspnea, dry cough, and basal reticular shadowing on imaging.
  • Busulphan:
    • Alkylating agent used in chemotherapy and bone marrow transplant conditioning
    • Mechanism: direct alveolar epithelial and endothelial injury → fibrosis
    • Pulmonary toxicity may appear months to years after exposure

Explanation of incorrect options

Clarithromycin (Option A): Antibiotic; pulmonary fibrosis is not a recognized side effect.

Amoxicillin (Option B): Antibiotic; does not cause interstitial lung disease.

Omeprazole (Option D): Acid-suppressive therapy; not associated with pulmonary fibrosis.

Drugs causing pulmonary fibrosis (AB3CTNM2):

  • Amiodarone
  • Bleomycin, Bromocriptine, Busulfan
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • TNF alpha inhibitors
  • Nitrofurantoin
  • Methotrexate, Mitomycin

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has long-standing breathlessness on exertion. He has been smoking 20 cigarettes a day for over 30 years. On examination, the patient is breathless with the use of accessory muscles and resting activation of the abdominal muscles. The chest is barrel-shaped. With regards to this case, which one of the following is known to be a predictor of mortality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In patients with severe COPD, a low BMI is a strong independent predictor of mortality, reflecting systemic effects and cachexia.

  • Clinical context:
    • Advanced COPD with chronic airflow limitation and emphysema
    • Use of accessory muscles and abdominal activation → severe disease
  • Mortality predictors in COPD:
    • BODE index (Body mass index, Obstruction [FEV1], Dyspnea [MRC scale], Exercise capacity [6MWT]) is validated for predicting survival in COPD
    • BMI reflects nutritional status and muscle mass, with low BMI associated with higher mortality
    • Other components (FEV1, dyspnea, exercise capacity) contribute, but BMI is an independent and easily measurable predictor

Explanation of incorrect options

Spirometry (Option A): FEV1 correlates with severity but is less predictive than the multidimensional BODE index.

Fibrotic changes (Option B): Not a primary determinant of prognosis in emphysematous COPD.

Arterial blood gases (Option D): Useful for assessing hypoxemia/hypercapnia but not a reliable long-term mortality predictor.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has a 2-year history of increasing shortness of breath. This is worse with exertion, e.g. climbing the stairs at home and is even slightly so at rest. He is a non-smoker. On examination, his pulse is 95 beats/min and his blood pressure is 140/95 mmHg. He has finger clubbing and a crackling noise at the end of inspiration over the bases of the lungs. There was no ankle oedema. Lung function tests show: FVC 2.5 L (predicted 3.2 ), FEV1 2.1 L (predicted 2.4), FEV1 % 76% (predicted 75%), Diffusing Capacity: Gas Transfer Factor for carbon monoxide: DLCO 17 ml/min/mmHg (predicted:25 ml/min/mmHg). Which one of the following diagnoses is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient shows progressive dyspnea, finger clubbing, basal end-inspiratory crackles, restrictive lung function, and reduced DLCO, which are classic features of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis).

  • Clinical features:
    • Middle-aged adult with gradual onset of exertional dyspnea
    • Bibasal inspiratory crackles ("Velcro-like")
    • Clubbing indicates chronic interstitial involvement
    • Non-smoker → reduces likelihood of COPD or emphysema
  • Pulmonary function tests:
    • FVC and FEV1 mildly reduced
    • FEV1/FVC ratio ~ normal → restrictive pattern
    • DLCO markedly reduced → impaired gas exchange typical of interstitial lung disease
  • Cryptogenic fibrosing alveolitis (CFA / idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis):
    • Chronic, progressive interstitial fibrosis of unknown etiology
    • Basal, peripheral lung involvement
    • HRCT shows reticular, honeycomb changes

Explanation of incorrect options

Aspergilloma (Option A): Usually occurs in pre-existing cavities; symptoms include hemoptysis; restrictive pattern not typical.

Guillain-Barre syndrome (Option B): Acute neuromuscular weakness; lung volumes may reduce but no clubbing or crackles.

Congestive cardiac failure (Option D): Dyspnea and crackles possible, but clubbing and restrictive patterns with low DLCO are atypical; often associated with peripheral edema.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with COPD is on maximal treatment. Which one of the following is likely to prevent further disease progression?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Smoking cessation is the only intervention proven to slow the decline in lung function and disease progression in COPD.

  • COPD progression:
    • Primarily driven by ongoing exposure to cigarette smoke and environmental irritants
    • Pharmacological treatments (bronchodilators, inhaled corticosteroids, anticholinergics) improve symptoms, reduce exacerbations, and enhance quality of life, but do not slow FEV1 decline significantly
  • Smoking cessation:
    • Proven to reduce the rate of FEV1 decline
    • Improves survival and decreases exacerbations
    • Most effective disease-modifying intervention
  • Other therapies:
    • Steroids → reduce inflammation, exacerbation frequency in selected patients, but do not prevent progression (Option A ruled out)
    • Beta agonists → symptom control, bronchodilation (Option B ruled out)
    • Tiotropium → improves symptoms and reduces exacerbations, slows FEV1 decline minimally, but less than smoking cessation (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A lifelong non-smoker is diagnosed with emphysema. Which of the following would be the most likely aetiological agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Coal workers' pneumoconiosis and long-term exposure to coal dust can lead to emphysema in non-smokers, especially in coal miners.

  • Clinical context:
    • Emphysema in non-smokers is often occupationally induced
    • Coal dust inhalation → small airway inflammation and alveolar wall destruction → emphysematous changes
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Dust particles cause chronic inflammation, leading to centrilobular emphysema, particularly in upper lobes
    • Risk increases with duration of exposure 

Explanation of incorrect options

Isocyanates (Option A): Cause airway hyperreactivity and asthma, not alveolar destruction leading to emphysema.

Steel (Option C): Occupational exposure may cause respiratory irritation, but emphysema is not typical.

Zinc (Option D): Can cause metal fume fever or acute pneumonitis; not chronic emphysema.

choices.text: Low VC, low FEV1, normal TLC, low RV/TLC
Low VC, low TLC, high RV/TLC

questions.text: In restrictive lung disease due to respiratory muscle weakness, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Respiratory muscle weakness causes reduced lung volumes (VC, TLC), but incomplete emptying leads to relative increase in RV/TLC ratio.

  • Mechanism in respiratory muscle weakness:
    • Weak inspiratory muscles → cannot fully inflate lungs → low TLC
    • Weak expiratory muscles → cannot fully exhale → residual volume remains high → RV/TLC ratio increases
    • Vital capacity (VC) is reduced
  • Spirometry findings:
    • FEV1 reduced proportionally with VC → FEV1/FVC ratio usually normal or slightly increased
    • TLC reduced → restrictive pattern
    • RV often normal or slightly increased, leading to high RV/TLC ratio

choices.text: Helium dilution is more accurate than body plethysmography in measuring residual olme.
Hypoxaemia at rest will improve with exercise.
The carbon monoxide transfer factor is reduced.

questions.text: Which ONE of the following is correct regarding severe bullous emphysema:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In severe bullous emphysema, alveolar destruction reduces the surface area for gas exchange, leading to a reduced carbon monoxide transfer factor (TLCO/DLCO).

  • Pathophysiology of bullous emphysema:
    • Characterized by enlarged airspaces (bullae) due to alveolar wall destruction
    • Bullae do not participate in gas exchange → effective alveolar surface area decreases
    • This leads to reduced DLCO/TLCO on pulmonary function testing
  • Other physiological changes:
    • Pulmonary compliance is increased (lungs are "floppy"), not reduced (Option C ruled out)
    • Hypoxemia at rest worsens with exercise due to impaired oxygen transfer (Option B ruled out)
    • Helium dilution underestimates residual volume because bullae are poorly ventilated and do not communicate well with airways; body plethysmography is more accurate (Option A ruled out)

choices.text: Pulmonary embolism and left bundle branch block

questions.text: Which of the following associations is matched correctly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) typically occurs in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis and presents with wheezing due to airway inflammation and obstruction.

  • ABPA features:
    • Caused by hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus fumigatus
    • Clinical: wheeze, cough, sputum with mucus plugs, sometimes hemoptysis
    • Radiology: central bronchiectasis, fleeting infiltrates
    • Pulmonary function: often shows obstructive pattern

Explanation of incorrect options

Pneumoconiosis and clubbing (Option A): Clubbing is usually absent in simple pneumoconiosis; may occur in advanced fibrosis but not classic.

Lung carcinoids and pleural effusion (Option B): Rarely cause pleural effusion; usually present with obstruction or hemoptysis.

Pulmonary embolism and left bundle branch block (Option C): PE may cause right heart strain → right bundle branch block, not LBBB.

Rectal pull-through and anastomosis for rectal prolapse.
Nebulised tobramycin for Pseudomonas colonisation of the lower respiratory tract.

questions.text: Which of the following is a recognised treatment for complications of cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nebulised tobramycin is used to treat and suppress chronic Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection in cystic fibrosis, a major contributor to morbidity and lung function decline.

  • Cystic fibrosis complications and their management:
    • Respiratory infections: Chronic Pseudomonas colonisation → use inhaled antibiotics like tobramycin or colistin to reduce bacterial load and preserve lung function.
    • Airway clearance: DNase is used to reduce mucus viscosity, not specifically to reinflate collapsed segments.
    • Gastrointestinal: Rectal prolapse may occur, but surgical pull-through is rarely first-line; supportive therapy is preferred.
    • Endocrine: CF-related diabetes is managed medically; pancreatic transplant is rarely performed.

Explanation of incorrect options

DNase to assist in reinflating collapsed lung segments (Option A): DNase reduces mucus viscosity and aids airway clearance, but does not directly reinflate collapsed lungs.

Rectal pull-through and anastomosis for rectal prolapse (Option B): Rarely indicated; initial management is conservative with stool softeners and physiotherapy.

Pancreatic transplant for diabetes mellitus (Option C): CF-related diabetes is typically managed with insulin therapy; transplant is not standard.

Outpatient regimens for cystic fibrosis management include:

  • Exogenous pancreatic enzymes taken with meals
  • Nutritional supplementation
  • Anti-inflammatory medication
  • Bronchodilators
  • Chronic or periodic administration of oral or aerosolised antibiotics (e.g., as maintenance therapy for patients with P. aeruginosa).
  • Recombinant DNase aerosols (degrade DNA strands that contribute to mucus viscosity) and nebulised hypertonic saline (serves to augment pcl depth, activate mucociliary clearance, and mobilise inspissated airway secretions) are administered routinely.
  • Chest physiotherapy several times each day is a standard means to promote clearance of airway mucus.
  • Among adults with CF, malabsorption, chronic inflammation, and endocrine abnormalities can lead to poor bone mineralisation, requiring treatment with vitamin D, calcium, and other measures
  • Rectal prolapse is usually idiopathic, occurring between 1 and 5 years. Intestinal parasites, malnutrition, acute diarrhoea, ulcerative colitis, pertussis, Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, meningocele, cystic fibrosis, and chronic constipation can also predispose to it. Following defecation, the prolapse usually resolves spontaneously or through manual reinsertion by the patient or parent.

choices.text: Bronchial wall thickening with ground-glass opacification

questions.text: Which of the following high-resolution computed tomographic findings is typical of cryptogenic organising pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia typically presents with patchy, often peripheral and bilateral consolidation on HRCT.

  • COP features on HRCT:
    • Patchy, bilateral consolidation, often peripheral or peribronchial
    • Ground-glass opacities may also be present but are less predominant
    • Migratory infiltrates are common
  • Differentiation from other patterns:
    • Bronchial wall thickening with ground-glass opacification (Option A): More typical of asthma or hypersensitivity pneumonitis
    • Basilar predominant, subpleural honeycomb change (Option B): Classic for usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP)/idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
    • Diffuse ground-glass opacification (Option C): Seen in acute interstitial pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or alveolar hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following therapeutic agents is/are approved for the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pirfenidone and nintedanib are antifibrotic agents approved for IPF that slow disease progression and decline in lung function.

  • Pirfenidone:
  • Oral antifibrotic and anti-inflammatory agent
    • Reduces decline in FVC and slows progression of IPF
    • Side effects: GI upset, rash, photosensitivity
  • Nintedanib:
    • Tyrosine kinase inhibitor
    • Inhibits pathways involved in fibroblast proliferation and deposition of extracellular matrix
    • Slows FVC decline and disease progression
    • Side effects: diarrhea, liver enzyme elevation
  • Mycophenolate (Option A):
    • Immunosuppressant
    • May be used in connective tissue disease-associated ILD, but not approved for IPF.

questions.text: The most common type of pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The acquired/autoimmune type of PAP, caused by anti-GM-CSF autoantibodies, accounts for ~90% of cases.

  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis is a rare lung disorder characterized by accumulation of surfactant within alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and progressive dyspnea.
  • Types of PAP:
    • Acquired/Autoimmune (~90%) - Most common.
      • Caused by autoantibodies against granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF).
      • This inhibits alveolar macrophage function → impaired surfactant clearance.
  • Secondary (~5-10%) - Associated with hematologic malignancies (e.g., leukemia, lymphoma), infections, or inhalation of toxic dusts (silica, aluminum, titanium, etc.).
  • Congenital (rare) - Due to mutations affecting surfactant protein genes or GM-CSF receptors. Presents in neonates/infants.
  • Diagnosis: HRCT shows "crazy-paving" pattern (ground-glass opacification with interlobular septal thickening).
  • Treatment: Whole-lung lavage is mainstay; GM-CSF therapy may be used in autoimmune type.

Explanation of incorrect options

Congenital (Option B): Rare, occurs in neonates/infants due to genetic mutations.

Associated with hematologic disease (Option C): Seen in secondary PAP, but far less common than autoimmune type.

Associated with metal dust exposure (Option D): Also a cause of secondary PAP, but not the most common.

questions.text: A labourer working at a shipyard developed complaints of insidious onset of dry cough and breathlessness at exertion. A chest X-ray revealed a lower-lobe predominant interstitial opacities with bilateral pleural effusion. Which of the following is the most common malignancy affecting these patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Occupational asbestos exposure (shipyard work) is most strongly linked to malignant pleural mesothelioma.

  • Asbestos exposure (common in shipyard, construction, insulation industries) is a well-known risk factor for both lung carcinoma and malignant mesothelioma.
  • The typical radiological features in asbestos-related lung disease include lower-lobe interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis), pleural plaques, and recurrent pleural effusions.
  • Among malignancies, while asbestos increases the risk of lung carcinoma (especially in smokers), the classic and most characteristic malignancy is malignant pleural mesothelioma.
  • Mesothelioma arises from mesothelial cells of pleura → present with progressive dyspnea, chest pain, pleural effusion, and diffuse pleural thickening.
  • Histology often shows epithelioid, sarcomatoid, or biphasic subtypes.

Explanation of incorrect options

Thymoma (Option A): Arises in anterior mediastinum; associated with myasthenia gravis, not asbestos.

Lung carcinoma (Option C): Asbestos does increase risk, especially synergistically with smoking, but mesothelioma is more characteristic of direct asbestos exposure.

Lymphoma (Option D): Involves mediastinum or lymph nodes, no association with asbestos.

questions.text: A 40-year-old factory worker presents with multiple joint pains. On examination, he has inflammatory joint pain in the small joints of both hands. What is the most likely underlying occupational exposure predisposing him to this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Silica exposure is strongly associated with the development of rheumatoid arthritis and other autoimmune diseases

  • Silicosis is caused by long-term inhalation of crystalline silica dust (e.g., in mining, stone cutting, quarrying, and sandblasting).
  • Apart from its pulmonary manifestations (upper lobe fibrosis, nodules, increased TB risk), silica has a strong association with autoimmune diseases such as:
    • Rheumatoid arthritis (Caplan's syndrome) → characterized by rheumatoid arthritis + pneumoconiosis + lung nodules.
    • Systemic sclerosis and lupus → also more common in silica-exposed workers.
  • The mechanism involves chronic immune activation and aberrant macrophage response leading to autoantibody formation.
  • Thus, this patient's symmetrical small-joint inflammatory arthritis (classic for rheumatoid arthritis) in the background of occupational exposure points to silica.

Explanation of incorrect options

Coal (Option A): Causes coal workers' pneumoconiosis, but not typically linked with autoimmune joint disease.

Asbestosis (Option C): Associated with pleural plaques, fibrosis, and mesothelioma, not arthritis.

Beryllium (Option D): Causes chronic berylliosis (granulomatous lung disease mimicking sarcoidosis), not rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: All of the following conditions cause upper lobe predominant fibrosis in the lung except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Asbestosis causes a lower lobe predominant fibrosis.

Causes of upper lobe fibrosis:(FASSTEN)

  • Farmer's lung (hypersensitivity pneumonitis) (Option C ruled out)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Silicosis (Option B ruled out)
  • TB
  • Eosinophilic granuloma (Langerhans-cell histiocytosis)
  • Neurofibromatosis
  • Coal worker's pneumoconiosis (Option A ruled out)

Lower Lung Disease (BADRASH)

  • Bronchiolitis obliterans with organising pneumonia (BOOP)/Cryptogenic Organising Pneumonia (COP)
  • Asbestosis
  • Drugs (nitrofurantoin, hydralazine, INH, amiodarone, many chemo drugs)
  • Rheumatologic disease
  • Aspiration
  • Scleroderma
  • Hamman-Rich (acute interstitial pneumonia) and IPF

questions.text: Which of the following pneumoconioses mimics the pathological pattern of sarcoidosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Berylliosis produces non-caseating granulomas in the lungs and hilar lymph nodes, closely resembling sarcoidosis both radiologically and pathologically.

  • Chronic beryllium disease (berylliosis) occurs in workers exposed to beryllium dust (aerospace, electronics, nuclear industries).
  • It is an immune-mediated granulomatous disease, not just due to dust accumulation.
  • Pathology: Non-caseating granulomas, identical to sarcoidosis.
  • Clinical features: Progressive dyspnea, cough, weight loss, fatigue.
  • Radiology: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial infiltrates (again mimicking sarcoidosis).
  • Differentiation from sarcoidosis: History of beryllium exposure and a positive beryllium lymphocyte proliferation test.

Explanation of incorrect options

Byssinosis (Option A): Caused by cotton dust exposure; produces asthma-like obstructive symptoms, not granulomas.

Asbestosis (Option B): Causes interstitial fibrosis, pleural plaques, and malignancies (mesothelioma, lung carcinoma), not sarcoid-like granulomas.

Coal worker's pneumoconiosis (Option D): Produces coal macules and nodules; complicated disease leads to progressive massive fibrosis, not non-caseating granulomas.
